Article.ArticleTitle: Interaction process between gaseous CH<sub>3</sub>I and NaCl particles: implication for iodine dispersion in the atmosphere.

AbstractText: Gaseous iodomethane (CH<sub>3</sub>I) is naturally emitted into the atmosphere by biological activity in oceans and during severe accidents (SAs) in nuclear power plants. In this latter case, a part of radioactive iodine such as <sup>131</sup>I may be released. Improving the knowledge of CH<sub>3</sub>I transport and reactivity in the atmosphere is important since they are strongly linked to first the cycle of ozone and second to the dispersion of radioactive CH<sub>3</sub>I with potential radiological consequences on both the environment and human health. Here, the interaction process of CH<sub>3</sub>I with NaCl as a surrogate of atmospheric aerosols was investigated under ambient air conditions by using Diffuse Reflectance Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The DRIFTS spectra of NaCl clearly evidenced CH<sub>3</sub>I adsorption on the NaCl particle surface. A part of CH<sub>3</sub>I ((1.68 ± 0.85) × 10<sup>14</sup> molecule per mg<sub>NaCl</sub>) was found to be strongly bonded to NaCl since no desorption was observed. The CH<sub>3</sub>I adsorption on the NaCl surface presented a 1<sup>st</sup> order kinetics relative to its gas phase concentration. The uptake coefficient was determined to be in the order of 10<sup>-11</sup>. These results show a low probability of CH<sub>3</sub>I to be taken up by halide-containing aerosols. These data are crucial for completing the iodine atmospheric chemical scheme.
